CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE his claim was turned down by the local employment office ( GPE ) on the ground that section CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) provided that only mothers could claim such an allowance when a child was born .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against that decision to ORG ( PERSON ) . He contended that that provision of LAW , under which men were not entitled to a parental leave allowance , was discriminatory and , therefore , unconstitutional .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal for the same reasons as the local employment office ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON lodged a complaint with ORG ) . He again argued that section CARDINAL ) of LAW was unconstitutional , as it was inconsistent with the principle of equality and LAW .
CARDINAL . On DATE , after considering the complaint in private , ORG declined to accept it for adjudication on the ground that it did not have sufficient prospects of success .

Referring to its case - law , ORG held that section DATE ) did not infringe the applicant ’s constitutional rights and was not contrary to LAW . It added that even if regard was had to recent statutory amendments ( section CARDINAL of LAW had been amended by a federal law of DATE see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , the applicant ’s complaint was unfounded , seeing that the legislature had a certain amount of time in which to adapt new rules to changes in society ( ORG an geänderte ORG ) .

NORP Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE , mothers were entitled to a parental leave allowance provided that , following the birth of their child , they took up to DATE parental leave and were eligible for maternity benefit ( PERSON – a welfare allowance payable to working mothers for a period of DATE after the birth ) .

CARDINAL . That section was amended by a federal law of CARDINAL DATE ( ORG no . DATE ) , which came into force on DATE . It is now provided that a father may claim a parental leave allowance if he is in employment , has primary responsibility for looking after the child and the child lives under the same roof . In addition , the mother must either be entitled to parental leave as a result of the birth and have waived that right in whole or in part or , if not entitled to parental leave , be prevented by her work from looking after the child .
However , the new rules apply only in respect of children born after DATE and therefore do not cover the applicant , whose child was born on DATE .
